item.title: Experiment_01
item.description:
• Simulation Experiment I
    • Generate Data
    • Run Regression
  • Simulation Experiment II
    • Generate Data
    • Run Regression
  • Simulation Experiment III
    • Generate Data
    • Run Regression
  • Simulation Experiment IV
    • Generate Data
    • Run Regression
  • Simulation Experiment V
    • Generate Data
    • Run Regression
  • Simulation Experiment VI
    • Generate Data
    • Run Regression

Simulation Experiment I

Generate Data

Firstly, generate the \(X_1\), \(X_2\), and \(\epsilon_i\)

library(magrittr) # 管道符所用的库
x.1 <- runif(100, min = 0, max = 5)
x.2 <- rnorm(100, mean = 5, sd = 2) + 0.5 * x.1
epsilon <- rnorm(100, mean = 0, sd = 1)
y <- 5 + 1 * x.1 + 0.5 * x.2 + epsilon

Then run the model, estimate \(\hat{\beta}_0\) and \(\hat{\beta}_1\) by the following model: \[Y_i=\beta_0+\beta_1X_{1i}+\beta_2X_{2i}+\epsilon_i\]

lm.y1 <- lm(y ~ 1 + x.1 + x.2)
summary(lm.y1)
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = y ~ 1 + x.1 + x.2)
## 
## Residuals:
##      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
## -3.01832 -0.48112  0.08427  0.54660  1.66419 
## 
## Coefficients:
##             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)  4.50631    0.31407   14.35   <2e-16 ***
## x.1          1.06987    0.07261   14.73   <2e-16 ***
## x.2          0.53415    0.04761   11.22   <2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 0.9621 on 97 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.8543,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.8513 
## F-statistic: 284.4 on 2 and 97 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16
coef(lm.y1)
## (Intercept)         x.1         x.2 
##   4.5063135   1.0698738   0.5341539

estimate \(\hat{\alpha}_0\) and \(\hat{\alpha}_1\) by the following model: \[Y_i=\alpha_0+\alpha_1X_{1i}+u_i\]

lm.y2 <- lm(y ~ 1 + x.1)
summary(lm.y2)
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = y ~ 1 + x.1)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -3.2265 -1.1955 -0.0322  1.1315  2.7580 
## 
## Coefficients:
##             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)   7.0950     0.3214   22.08   <2e-16 ***
## x.1           1.3985     0.1002   13.96   <2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 1.451 on 98 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.6653,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.6619 
## F-statistic: 194.8 on 1 and 98 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16
coef(lm.y2)
## (Intercept)         x.1 
##    7.095001    1.398476

Run Regression

Repeat 1000 times:

beta <- c()
alpha <- c()
for (i in 1:1000) {
    x.1 <- runif(100, min = 0, max = 5)
    x.2 <- rnorm(100, mean = 5, sd = 2) + 0.5 * x.1
    epsilon <- rnorm(100, mean = 0, sd = 1)
    y <- 5 + 1 * x.1 + 0.5 * x.2 + epsilon
    beta <- lm(y ~ 1 + x.1 + x.2) %>%
        coef() %>%
        .[2] %>%
        c(beta, .)
    alpha <- lm(y ~ 1 + x.1) %>%
        coef() %>%
        .[2] %>%
        c(alpha, .)
}

print(mean(beta))
## [1] 0.9996362
print(mean(alpha))
## [1] 1.250701

From the result, we can see that \(\beta_1\) is close to the true value, comparing to the real value, while \(\alpha_1\) is not close to the true value.

Simulation Experiment II

Model: \[Y_i=\beta_0+\beta_1X_{1i}+\beta_2X_{2i}+\epsilon_i\]

Estimating models:

  1. \[Y_i=\beta_0+\beta_1X_{1i}+\beta_2X_{2i}\epsilon\]
  2. \[Y_i=\alpha_0+\alpha_1X_{1i}+u_i\]

Generate Data

This time, we put the result of coefficient of \(x_1\) in a function.

coef_of_x1 <- function() {
    beta_zero <- 5
    beta_one <- 1
    beta_two <- 0.5
    x_1 <- runif(100, 0, 5)
    x_2 <- rnorm(100, mean = 5, sd = 2)
    epsilon <- rnorm(100, mean = 0, sd = 1)

    # Follows the model:
    # beta one hat:
    y <- beta_zero + beta_one * x_1 + beta_two * x_2 + epsilon
    beta_one_hat <- lm(y ~ 1 + x_1 + x_2) %>%
        coef() %>%
        .[2]
    alpha_one_hat <- lm(y ~ 1 + x_1) %>%
        coef() %>%
        .[2]
    c(beta_one_hat, alpha_one_hat) %>% return()
}

Run Regression

Then, repeat it and get the mean values of \(\hat{\beta}_1\) and \(\hat{\alpha}_1\)

beta_one_hat_list <- c()
alpha_one_hat_list <- c()
for (i in 1:1000) {
    beta_one_hat_list <- c(beta_one_hat_list, coef_of_x1()[1])
    alpha_one_hat_list <- c(alpha_one_hat_list, coef_of_x1()[2])
}
# mean value of beta one hat:
print(mean(beta_one_hat_list))
## [1] 1.001365
# mean value of alpha one hat:
print(mean(alpha_one_hat_list))
## [1] 0.9997646

From the result, we can see that \(\hat{\beta}_1\) and \(\hat{\alpha}_1\) are both close to the true value.

Simulation Experiment III

Model: \[Y_1=\beta_0+\beta_1X_{1i}+\epsilon_i\]

Estimating models:

  1. \[Y_i=\beta_0+\beta_1X_{1i}+\beta_2X_{2i}+\epsilon_i\]
  2. \[Y_i=\alpha_0+\alpha_1X_{1i}+u_i\]

Generate Data

Same thing.

coef_of_x1 <- function() {
    beta_zero <- 5
    beta_one <- 1
    x_1 <- runif(100, 0, 5)
    x_2 <- rnorm(100, 5, 2)
    epsilon <- rnorm(100) # 默认为标准正态分布
    y <- beta_zero + beta_one * x_1 + epsilon
    beta_one_hat <- lm(y ~ 1 + x_1 + x_2) %>%
        coef() %>%
        .[2]
    alpha_one_hat <- lm(y ~ 1 + x_1) %>%
        coef() %>%
        .[2]
    return(c(beta_one_hat, alpha_one_hat))
}

Run Regression

repeat 1000 times:

beta_one_hat_list <- c()
alpha_one_hat_list <- c()
for (i in 1:1000) {
    beta_one_hat_list <- c(beta_one_hat_list, coef_of_x1()[1])
    alpha_one_hat_list <- c(alpha_one_hat_list, coef_of_x1()[2])
}

# mean value of beta one hat
print(mean(beta_one_hat_list))
## [1] 0.9975254
# mean value of alpha one hat
print(mean(alpha_one_hat_list))
## [1] 1.003733

The result shows that both \(\hat{\beta}_1\) and \(\hat{\alpha}_1\) are close to the true value.

实际上，在第一个回归中，\(x_2\) 的系数显著水平不高（或者说在0.01不显著）

## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = y ~ 1 + x_1 + x_2)
## 
## Residuals:
##      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
## -2.53164 -0.56450  0.00336  0.58411  2.49718 
## 
## Coefficients:
##             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)  5.24848    0.31173  16.837   <2e-16 ***
## x_1          0.97502    0.06759  14.425   <2e-16 ***
## x_2         -0.03363    0.04549  -0.739    0.462    
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 0.9079 on 97 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.6905,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.6841 
## F-statistic: 108.2 on 2 and 97 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

Simulation Experiment IV

Model: \[Y_i=\beta_0+\beta_1X_{1i}+\epsilon_i\]

Estimating models:

  1. \[Y_i=\beta_0+\beta_1\tilde{X}_{1i}+\epsilon_i\]
  2. \[Y_i=\alpha_0+\alpha_1X_{1i}+\epsilon_i\]

Generate Data

coef_of_x1 <- function() {
    beta_zero <- 5
    beta_one <- 1
    x_1 <- runif(100, 0, 5)
    ita <- rnorm(100, 0, 2)
    epsilon <- rnorm(100)
    x_1_tilde <- x_1 + ita
    y <- beta_zero + beta_one * x_1 + epsilon
    beta_one_hat <- lm(y ~ 1 + x_1_tilde) %>%
        coef() %>%
        .[2]
    alpha_one_hat <- lm(y ~ 1 + x_1) %>%
        coef() %>%
        .[2]
    return(c(beta_one_hat, alpha_one_hat))
}

Run Regression

beta_one_hat_list <- c()
alpha_one_hat_list <- c()

for (i in 1:1000) {
    beta_one_hat_list <- c(beta_one_hat_list, coef_of_x1()[1])
    alpha_one_hat_list <- c(alpha_one_hat_list, coef_of_x1()[2])
}
# mean value of beta one hat
print(mean(beta_one_hat_list))
## [1] 0.3445264

# mean value of alpha one hat
print(mean(alpha_one_hat_list))
## [1] 0.9996002

So, \(\tilde{X}_{1i}\)’s coefficient \(\hat{\beta}_1\) is close to the true value, while the coefficient of \(X_{1i}\), \(\hat{\alpha}_1\) is not close to the true value.

Simulation Experiment V

Model: \[Y_i=\beta_0+\beta_1X_{1i}+\epsilon_i\]

Estimating models:

  1. \[\tilde{Y_i}=\beta_0+\beta_1X_{1i}+\epsilon_1\]
  2. \[Y_i=\alpha_0+\alpha_1X_{1i}+u_i\]

Generate Data

coef_of_x1 <- function() {
    beta_zero <- 5
    beta_one <- 1
    x_1 <- runif(100, 0, 5)
    ita <- rnorm(100, 0, 2)
    epsilon <- rnorm(100)
    y <- beta_zero + beta_one * x_1 + epsilon
    y_tilde <- y + ita
    beta_one_hat <- lm(y_tilde ~ 1 + x_1) %>%
        coef() %>%
        .[2]
    alpha_one_hat <- lm(y ~ 1 + x_1) %>%
        coef() %>%
        .[2]
    return(c(beta_one_hat, alpha_one_hat))
}

Run Regression

beta_one_hat_list <- c()
alpha_one_hat_list <- c()
for (i in 1:1000) {
    beta_one_hat_list <- c(beta_one_hat_list, coef_of_x1()[1])
    alpha_one_hat_list <- c(alpha_one_hat_list, coef_of_x1()[2])
}

# mean value of beta one hat
print(mean(beta_one_hat_list))
## [1] 0.9944924

# mean value of alpha one hat
print(mean(alpha_one_hat_list))
## [1] 1.000349

We can see from the result that coefficients of \(X_{1i}\) in both models are close to the true value.

Simulation Experiment VI

Supply curve:

\[Q_s=\beta_0+\beta_1P+\beta_2X+\epsilon_1\]

Demand curve:

\[Q_d=\alpha_0+\alpha_1P+\alpha_2Z+\epsilon_2\]

In equilibrium:

\[P=\pi_0+\pi_1X+\pi_2Z+u\]

Generate Data

Firstly, we simulate the variables.

alpha_0 <- beta_0 <- 0
alpha_1 <- beta_2 <- -1
alpha_2 <- beta_1 <- 1

x <- rnorm(100, 10, 169)
z <- rnorm(100, 5, 400)
epsilon_1 <- rnorm(100, 0, 4)
epsilon_2 <- rnorm(100, 0, 100)

pi_0 <- (alpha_0 - beta_0) / (beta_1 - alpha_1)
pi_1 <- (-beta_2) / (beta_1 - alpha_1)
pi_2 <- alpha_2 / (beta_1 - alpha_1)
u <- (epsilon_2 - epsilon_1) / (beta_1 - alpha_1)

Then, we calculate P and Q

p <- pi_0 + pi_1 * x + pi_2 * z + u
q <- beta_0 + beta_1 * p + beta_2 * x + epsilon_1

Run Regression

The regressions we try to run:

  1. \[Q=a_0+a_1P+a_2Z+\epsilon_1\]
  2. \[Q=b_0+b_1P+b_2X+\epsilon_2\]
  3. \[Q=c_0+c_1P+c_2X+c_3Z+\epsilon_3\]
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = q ~ 1 + p + z)
## 
## Residuals:
##      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
## -181.232  -54.685   -4.886   55.174  213.415 
## 
## Coefficients:
##             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept) -3.25495    8.50707  -0.383    0.703    
## p           -0.64957    0.07829  -8.297 6.24e-13 ***
## z            0.78185    0.04129  18.935  < 2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 83.36 on 97 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.8623,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.8595 
## F-statistic: 303.8 on 2 and 97 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = q ~ 1 + p + x)
## 
## Residuals:
##      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
## -11.5079  -1.7750  -0.0509   2.1640   8.6378 
## 
## Coefficients:
##             Estimate Std. Error  t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)  0.41784    0.38371    1.089    0.279    
## p            1.00111    0.00196  510.641   <2e-16 ***
## x           -0.99778    0.00211 -472.878   <2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 3.761 on 97 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.9997,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.9997 
## F-statistic: 1.729e+05 on 2 and 97 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = q ~ 1 + p + x + z)
## 
## Residuals:
##      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
## -11.5659  -1.9775  -0.1094   2.3549   8.7502 
## 
## Coefficients:
##              Estimate Std. Error  t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)  0.385370   0.381107    1.011    0.314    
## p            1.014194   0.008340  121.607   <2e-16 ***
## x           -1.004335   0.004569 -219.836   <2e-16 ***
## z           -0.006509   0.004034   -1.613    0.110    
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 3.731 on 96 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.9997,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.9997 
## F-statistic: 1.172e+05 on 3 and 96 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

We can put together the steps above and formulate a function to return the coefficients.

get_coefficients <- function() {
    alpha_0 <- beta_0 <- 0
    alpha_1 <- beta_2 <- -1
    alpha_2 <- beta_1 <- 1

    x <- rnorm(100, 10, 169)
    z <- rnorm(100, 5, 400)
    epsilon_1 <- rnorm(100, 0, 4)
    epsilon_2 <- rnorm(100, 0, 100)

    pi_0 <- (alpha_0 - beta_0) / (beta_1 - alpha_1)
    pi_1 <- (-beta_2) / (beta_1 - alpha_1)
    pi_2 <- alpha_2 / (beta_1 - alpha_1)
    u <- (epsilon_2 - epsilon_1) / (beta_1 - alpha_1)

    p <- pi_0 + pi_1 * x + pi_2 * z + u
    q <- beta_0 + beta_1 * p + beta_2 * x + epsilon_1

    a_hat <- lm(q ~ 1 + p + z) %>%
        coef() %>%
        .[2]
    b_hat <- lm(q ~ 1 + p + x) %>%
        coef() %>%
        .[2]
    c_hat <- lm(q ~ 1 + p + x + z) %>%
        coef() %>%
        .[2]

    return(c(a_hat, b_hat, c_hat))
}

Then, repeatly run it 1000 times, and gather the coefficient lists

a_hat_list <- c()
b_hat_list <- c()
c_hat_list <- c()

for (i in 1:1000) {
    a_hat_list <- c(a_hat_list, get_coefficients()[1])
    b_hat_list <- c(b_hat_list, get_coefficients()[2])
    c_hat_list <- c(c_hat_list, get_coefficients()[3])
}

# print out the result
print(mean(a_hat_list))
## [1] -0.4830255
print(mean(b_hat_list))
## [1] 0.9998708
print(mean(c_hat_list))
## [1] 0.9967457

  • From the regression results, we can conclude that \(\hat{b}\) and \(\hat{c}\) are unbiased to 1.

  • Also, in the third regression we can see the coefficient of Z is insignificant

  • However, \(\hat{a}\) is not close to -1
